description: From Middle English elit, from Old French elit, eslit (“chosen, elected”) past participle of elire, eslire (“to choose, elect”), from Latin eligere (“to choose, elect”), with past participle electus; see elect.

adjectives.description: elite (comparative eliter or more elite, superlative elitest or most elite)

entries.meaning: Of high birth or social position; aristocratic or patrician.
Representing the choicest or most select of a group.
examples: Not since Coventry in 1992 has a Premier League side kicked off a campaign with an all-English XI but things have reached the point where, of the 61 signings who have cost the elite division's 20 clubs a transfer fee this summer, only 12 have involved Englishmen.

entries.meaning: A special group or social class of people which have a superior intellectual, social or economic status as, the elite of society.
Someone who is among the best at a certain task.
examples: Is there a nobler or more disinterested aim than to educate the cadres, the elites of tomorrow?

entries.meaning: (typography) A typeface with 12 characters per inch.
